stattutor_problem.title: Risk Factors for Low Birth Weight
stattutor_problem.background:
Low birth weight is an outcome that has been of concern to physicians for years. This is due to the fact that infant mortality rates and birth defect rates are very high for babies with low birth weight. A woman's behavior during pregnancy (including diet, smoking habits, and obtaining prenatal care) can greatly alter her chances of carrying the baby to term and, consequently, of delivering a baby of normal birth weight.

In this exercise, we will use a 1986 study (Hosmer and Lemeshow (2000), Applied Logistic Regression: Second Edition) in which data were collected from 189 women (of whom 59 had low birth weight infants) at the Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, MA (an academic, research, and teaching hospital that serves as the western campus of Tufts University School of Medicine and is the only Level 1 trauma center in western Massachusetts). The goal of the study was to identify risk factors associated with giving birth to a low birth weight baby.

variable.name: LOW
variable.description: Low birth weight (0=No (birth weight >= 2500 g) 1=Yes (birth weight < 2500 g)

variable.name: LWT
variable.description: Weight of mother at the last menstrual period (in pounds)

variable.name: FTV
variable.description: Number of physician visits during the first trimester

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten mothers in the dataset, how many gave birth to a baby whose weight was normal?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single mother, so the first ten rows represent the first ten patients. Look at the "Low" column and count how many of the first ten mothers gave birth to a baby whose weight was normal (coded as 0).
If you look at the "Low" column, you'll see that eight of the first ten mothers gave birth to a baby whose weight was normal (coded as 0). These are mothers 1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, and 10.

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten mothers in the data set, how old was the mother who gave birth to the baby with the lowest birth weight?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single mother, so the first ten rows represent the first ten patients. Look at the "BWT" column (representing the actual birth weight), look for the lowest weight (among the first ten), and then report the mother's AGE.
If you look at the BWT column, you'll find that the lowest birth weight among the first ten is 1818 grams, which is the weight of the baby of mother #8. The age of this mother is 32.

cdf_question.text: Out of the first ten mothers who did not visit a physician during the first trimester, how many gave birth to a low birth weight baby?

hints.hint: To answer each of the questions in this step, you'll need to look at the dataset you opened at the beginning of your StatTutor session, and examine the first few cases (rows).

In this dataset, each row represents a single mother. Scroll through the dataset and consider the first ten mothers who did not visit a physician during the first trimester (FTV=0). Now count how many of them gave birth to a low birth weight baby (LOW=1).

The first ten mothers who did not visit a physician during the first trimester are 3, 6, 8, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 18, and 19. If you'll look at the LOW column, you'll find that six of those mothers gave birth to a low birth weight baby (LOW=1). These are mothers # 8, 12, 13, 14, 18, and 19.

our_answer.text: We are not given any information about how the 189 women were chosen to participate in the study, except the fact that they were all treated at the Baystate Medical Center.

main_question.text: Do the data provide evidence that the occurrence of low birth weight is significantly related to whether or not the mother smoked during pregnancy?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering how/if smoking effects the occurrence of low birth weight, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: Smoking is known to be a risk factor, and therefore it would be reasonable to expect the data will show that smoking has a significant effect on the occurrence of low birth weight infants.
25.22% of mothers who did not smoke had a low birth weight baby, and 40.54% of mother who did smoke had a low birth weight baby.
25.22% of mothers who did not smoke had a low birth weight baby, and 40.54% of mother who did smoke had a low birth weight baby.
Here is the Excel output:
25.22% of mothers who did not smoke had a low birth weight baby, and 40.54% of mother who did smoke had a low birth weight baby.
25.22% of mothers who did not smoke had a low birth weight baby, and 40.54% of mother who did smoke had a low birth weight baby.

determine_mfa.focus: examining the relationship between two categorical variables

ha.first: two cat vars are not independent

our_answer.text: The test statistic is 4.924, and the p-value is .026. Since .026 < .05 we reject Ho.

consider_results.question: What do the results indicate about the relationship between smoking during pregnancy and the occurrence of low birth weight?

our_answer.text:
• The exploratory analysis revealed that low birth weight babies are more prevalent among mothers who smoke during pregnancy than among mothers who don't (40.54 vs. 25.22%).

  • The formal statistical test produced a p-value of .026 indicating that the data provide enough evidence to conclude that low birth weight is significantly related to smoking.

• The results are not surprising. They are consistent with what we expected.

  • The risks associated with smoking, specifically smoking during pregnancy, should be communicated to pregnant women in as many ways as possible (including pamphlets, Internet, prenatal caregivers, etc.).

main_question.text: Do the results of the study provide significant evidence that the race of the mother is a factor in the occurrence of low birth weight?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering whether the occurrence of low birth weight is related to the mother's race, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: It would be reasonable to expect some differences between races in the occurrence of low birth weight babies. It would be interesting to see whether the data provide enough evidence to conclude that race is indeed a risk factor.
23.96% of the white mothers had a low birth weight baby. 42.31% of black mothers had a low birth weight baby. 37.31% of mothers in the "other" group had a low birth weight baby.
23.96% of the white mothers had a low birth weight baby. 42.31% of black mothers had a low birth weight baby. 37.31% of mothers in the "other" group had a low birth weight baby.

determine_mfa.focus: examining the relationship between two categorical variables

ha.first: two cat vars are not independent

our_answer.text: The test statistic is 5.005, and the p-value is .082 > .05. Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is 5.005, and the p-value is .082 > .05. Ho cannot be rejected.
Here is the Excel output:
The p-value is .082 > .05. Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is 5.005, and the p-value is .082 > .05. Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is 5.005, and the p-value is .082 > .05. Ho cannot be rejected.

consider_results.question: What do the results indicate about the relationship between race and the occurrence of low birth weight?

our_answer.text:
• In the exploratory data analysis, we saw some differences in the occurrence of low birth weight babies among mothers of different races.

  • The formal statistical test, however, produced a p-value of .082 indicating that the data do not provide enough evidence to conclude that low birth weight is indeed related to race. In other words, even though the data showed some differences between the races, the evidence in not strong enough to conclude that race is a risk factor for low birth weight.

• Interesting results. It was actually surprising that the formal analysis did not find a significant race effect.

  • Since we found no association between race and low birth weight, there is no practical use for this information.

main_question.text: Are there significant differences in age between mothers who gave birth to low weight babies and those whose baby's weight was normal?

consider_question.question: Before analyzing the data and discovering whether there are significant age differences between low and normal birth weight mothers, try to predict what the data will show (use your own experience and intuition).

our_answer.text: It is known that age is a risk factor for complications during pregnancy, where the older the mother, the more likely the occurrence. It would be reasonable to expect that the data will support that low birth weight may be one of the issues for older mothers.

Center: The median age of mothers who did not have a low birth weight baby is slightly higher than that of mothers who did (23 vs. 22).

Spread: There is more variation in the age of mothers who did not have a low birth weight baby (IQR: 9 vs. 6, Range: 31 vs. 20).

Outliers: There is one outlier: a mother who was 45 years old and did not have a low birth weight baby.

determine_mfa.test: two sample t-test for two means

our_answer.text: The test statistic is t = 1.77, and the p-value is 0.078 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is t = 1.77, and the p-value is 0.078 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
Here is the Excel output:
The p-value is 0.078 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is t = 1.77, and the p-value is 0.078 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.
The test statistic is t = 1.77, and the p-value is 0.078 > .05, indicating that Ho cannot be rejected.

consider_results.question: What do the results indicate about the differences in age between mothers who gave birth to low birth weight babies and those whose baby's weight was normal?

our_answer.text:
• The exploratory data analysis revealed some small differences in age between mothers who had an occurrence of a low birth weight baby and mothers who didn't.

  • Indeed, the formal statistical test produced a p-value of .078 indicating that the data do not provide enough evidence to conclude that there are differences in age between the two groups of mothers.

• These are interesting results. Completely opposite of what we thought...

  • Although age does not appear to be a factor for low birth weight babies, this does not rule out the possibility of other complications for pregnancies at an older or at very young ages.

In this exercise we examined potential risk factors for the occurrence of a low birth weight baby. We found that smoking is a significant risk factor, and race has some effect, but the data did not provide strong enough evidence to conclude that it is a risk factor. We also found that there are no significant differences in age between mothers who had a low birth weight baby and mothers who didn't.

• Since this is an observational study, we cannot make any causal conclusions. However, identifying risk factors is an important finding regardless of whether these risk factors have a direct causal effect on low birth weight. It should be noted that we can never conduct a randomized experiment for factors such as smoking, race, or age. However, as long as we have a sample that accounts for the diversity in the population, the results are noteworthy.

  • Even though we are not specifically told this is a random sample, this was a major medical study conducted at a major research center. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that our sample accounts for the diversity in the population of pregnant women and the results can be thought of as more general.
